importantDates.descriptionOfWhyDateIsRelevant: Lindsay Sandiford was arrested in 2012 at Bali airport following the discovery of cocaine in her suitcase.
Indonesia’s highest court upheld Lindsay Sandiford’s death sentence in 2013.
Shahab Shahabadi was arrested in 2014 and sentenced to life imprisonment for methamphetamine trafficking.
The repatriation agreement between Britain and Indonesia was signed on October 21, 2025, to bring both prisoners back to their home countries.

importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: The timeline spans from Sandiford’s arrest in 2012 to the 2025 repatriation deal, highlighting a 13-year legal and diplomatic struggle.

keyTakeAways: A British grandmother, Lindsay Sandiford, was spared execution in Indonesia after a bilateral agreement between the UK and Indonesia to repatriate her and another British prisoner, Shahab Shahabadi.
Lindsay Sandiford, 68, was arrested in 2012 with 3.8 kilograms of cocaine hidden in her suitcase, claiming she was forced to carry it due to threats to her children.
She was sentenced to death by firing squad in 2013, and Indonesia’s highest court upheld the sentence.
Shahab Shahabadi, 35, has been serving a life sentence since 2014 for methamphetamine trafficking involving shipments from Iran to Jakarta.
Both prisoners face serious health and legal challenges; Sandiford is seriously ill and has been examined by a British Consul in Bali.
The UK Foreign and Commonwealth Secretary, Yvette Cooper, signed the repatriation agreement with Indonesia’s Senior Minister of Law, Yusril Ihza Mahendra.
Indonesia has a significant number of foreign nationals on death row—nearly 100—mostly for drug-related offenses, with the last executions in 2016.
Indonesia is a major drug smuggling hub despite strict drug laws, due in part to targeting of young populations by international drug syndicates.
The repatriation deal reflects broader international cooperation in human rights and prisoner repatriation, especially in cases of foreign nationals facing death penalties.
This case is relevant to global debates on capital punishment, particularly in countries with strict anti-drug laws that disproportionately affect foreigners.

summaryOfNewsArticle: A British woman, Lindsay Sandiford, aged 68, was sentenced to death by firing squad in Indonesia in 2013 after being arrested in 2012 with 3.8 kilograms of cocaine hidden in her suitcase. She claimed she was coerced into carrying the drugs to protect her children. The sentence was upheld by Indonesia’s highest court. A separate British prisoner, Shahab Shahabadi, has been serving a life sentence since 2014 for methamphetamine trafficking. Both are now being repatriated under a bilateral agreement signed on October 21, 2025, between the UK and Indonesia. The UK Foreign Secretary, Yvette Cooper, and Indonesia’s Senior Minister of Law, Yusril Ihza Mahendra, signed the deal, citing health concerns and humanitarian grounds. The repatriation reflects broader international efforts to prevent capital punishment for foreign nationals, especially in countries with strict drug laws like Indonesia, which has nearly 100 foreigners on death row and has not executed anyone since 2016. This case highlights tensions between strict drug enforcement and human rights protections in global drug trafficking enforcement.
title: British Grandmother Spared Firing Squad in Repatriation Deal with Indonesia
